Since the facility is normally unmanned, Water Operators are typically the only personnel on site.  In case a chlorine leak is detected at the facility, the on-call Duty Operator is alerted via the SCADA system.  The Duty Operator alerts the Utilities Superintendent and/or Manager and/or Supervisor, and immediately responds to the alarm.  Upon arrival, the Duty Operator determines the severity of the incident and whether the Fire Department and Hazardous Materials Response Team should be called to respond to the emergency.  The Duty Operator assignment is made on a rotating basis between the various trained and qualified Water Operations staff.  Each water operator has the necessary hazardous materials training to be considered qualified to assess the severity of a potential chlorine leak.


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The recent Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study (April 2024) and Seismic Assessment (May 2024) provided mitigation measures to improve safety at the Carlsbad MWD Maerkle facility.  The PHA Study included a detailed review of the recommended action items generated during the previous PHA study, a discussion of the facilitys recent accident history, the completion of chlorine industry safety checklists, and the application of a Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) analysis that reviewed potential hazards and operational issues with the chlorine systems.  A Three-Year Compliance Audit was also conducted in June 2022 that identified compliance-related issues to ensure the District is maintaining full implementation of the PSM and RMP programs.

The Water Operations Department PSM Committee meets routinely (typically quarterly) to ensure that items recommended in studies such as PHAs, Compliance Audits, Seismic Assessments, and regulatory inspections are addressed in a timely manner.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

An emergency planning and response policy has been developed for Carlsbad MWDs Maerkle Facility and is maintained by the Water Utilities department.  It is based on Cal-OSHAs requirements for Emergency Action Plan (CCR Title 8, Section 3220), as well as EPAs Emergency Response Plan.

District personnel receive annual training regarding the emergency response procedures and the evacuation plan.  In the event of a chlorine leak, all personnel are directed to evacuate the facility.  Notifications of response agencies as well the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) is also detailed the Emergency Response policy.

The Emergency Action Plan contains procedures detailing how Carlsbad MWD Utilities department will react to chlorine releases and other emergencies such as fires, earthquakes, power outages, etc.  The facilitys Emergency Action / Response Policy includes the following elements:

  --  Key Facility Personnel and Responsibilities
  --  Outside Agency Notification Contact Information
  --  Detailed Action Plans for Internal Departments
  --  First Aid Procedures
  --  Emergency Medical Treatment Procedures
  --  Evacuation Plans + Assembly Areas
  --  Description for Handling Small Chlorine Leaks
  --  Details of Outside Assistance Available
  --  Incident Command System
  --  Initial and Refresher Training

The Emergency Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, chlorine health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  Emergency response policies and protocols have been coordinated with the Carlsbad Fire Department and the San Diego County Hazardous Incident Response Team (HIRT) to ensure a mutual understanding of roles and responsibilities during a chlorine emergency situation. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

EPA's RMP regulation defines accident as the following:

The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.

The release must have caused at least one of the following:

- On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (§68.42(a)); or
- Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (§68.42(a)).

Based on the above definition and an investigation into the accident history at the Carlsbad MWD Upper and Lower Maerkle Stations conducted at the time of the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation study (April 2024), there have been no accidental releases of chlorine at the either the Upper or the Lower Maerkle Stations that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 10 pounds in the last five years (April 2019 to April 2024) or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of hazardous material for the Five-Year Accident History at the facility. REVENTION STEPS

The Carlsbad MWD chlorine systems have many safety features.  Much of the safety design is inherent in the policies and procedures that are used to manage the operations of the chlorine processes.  For example, the Carlsbad MWD chlorine systems operate in accordance with Cal-OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation and the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.

The District maintains and implements a rigorous policy of inspections, testing, and maintenance for all chlorine components + auxiliary systems.  This comprehensive policy is based on both manufacturer recommendations, industry standards (ex: Chlorine Institute), and recognized generally accepted good engineering practices.  It includes regular routine visual inspection w/ a log sheet to record system parameters, replacement of components as recommended, overhaul / service on key parts such as vacuum regulators and rotameters, testing and calibration of chlorine leak detectors, testing of motor actuated automatic closing mechanisms and scrubbers, etc.

In the event that the primary engineering or administration controls at the facility fail and result in a release of chlorine, there are four mechanisms in the facility to minimize the impact: 1) chlorine gas detectors, 2) visual/audible alarms, 3) chlorine scrubber system, and 4) halogen motorized automatic shut-off valves.

The chlorine detectors located in the chlorine rooms at both stations trigger local alarm annunciators, as well as notifying the Water Operators via the SCADA telemetry system.  The leak detection system also triggers the motorized automatic shut off valves to close the one-ton container valve (equipped with battery backup power), as well as activating the scrubber system that draws in any chlorine gas in the room to be neutralized.  The Scrubber for each facility has a capacity to neutralize 2,000 pounds of chlorine (one full ton container) with a 99%+ rate of effectiveness.

Downstream of the vacuum regulator, chlorine gas is fed to manually-adjustable rotameters located in an adjacent room.  The chlorine can be distributed to various points in the water system as needed based on water sampling results.  Each process feeds chlorine gas into solution at an injector where it is mixed with water, which neutralizes the hazards of the chlorine gas.

The chlorine systems are integrated into the Districts SCADA system, which provides remote access to system parameters and operating conditions, as well as security monitoring.  The SCADA system provides a readout of the weight of the one-ton container that is on-line, status of facility access doors, and leak detection monitoring.

The one-ton containers are stored in the Chlorine Tank Room, which is protected by a scrubber with a capacity to neutralize up to 2,000 pounds of chlorine gas.  The scrubber is activated based on the alarm status of a chlorine leak detector located in the Chlorine Tank Room.  The scrubber system and auxiliary components (ex: air blower) are function tested on a monthly basis by water operators.

** Upper Maerkle Station

The maximum quantity of chlorine maintained at the Upper Maerkle Station is 2 one-ton containers (4,000 pounds).

The design and operation of the chlorine system (upstream of the chlorinators) at the Upper Maerkle Station is very similar to that of the Lower Maerkle Station.  Only two rotameters are used at the Upper Maerkle Station.  Prior to injection, the chlorine gas passes through a chlorine dioxide generator that uses sodium hypochlorite as a reagent to create chlorine dioxide.  The process feeds this chlorine dioxide into solution at the injector where it is mixed with water.  Similar chlorine detection, Scrubber System, and SCADA monitoring equipment are located at the Upper Maerkle Station.

** Lower Maerkle Station

A maximum of five (5) one-ton containers of chlorine can be stored in the chlorine room at any one time.  Empty containers are also stored in the chlorine room until being picked up by the chlorine vendor during the next chemical delivery.

Two (2) one-ton containers are on-line at any one time where one is in operation and the other is on standby.  The on-line containers are each placed on a digital scale that indicates the remaining weight of chlorine in each of the on-line one-ton containers to allow system operators to monitor usage and plan ahead for ordering more chlorine.  The chlorine system is operated entirely under vacuum conditions with a vacuum regulator attached to each of the one-ton container valves.  Each one-ton container is positioned so that the valves are vertically aligned.  The system connections are made at the upper container valve to ensure that chlorine gas (not liquid) is drawn out of the container.
 
Chlorine gas is drawn from the active one-ton container through an automatic switchover / vacuum regulator.  The automatic switchover regulator valves control which container is actively feeding chlorine to the system.  A vacuum (negative pressure) is created when process water is pumped through the injectors.  This flow generates a vacuum which opens the vacuum regulator.  If a loss of vacuum were to occur in the line downstream of the vacuum regulator, a diaphragm in the vacuum regulator will close, stopping any chlorine gas from escaping from the container. Carlsbad MWD has formal and informal facility training programs for all employees.  Hazardous Materials training, (Awareness Level, 8-Hour HAZWOPER), is given to all water operations staff.  Water Operators are authorized to go onsite and assess a potential emergency from outside the chlorine buildings.  All employees receive specific chlorine-related training during new employee orientation, as well as extensive refresher training that is conducted on a continual basis.  CMWD Water Operators are trained to call for outside assistance (911 and/or San Diego HazMat Team) to respond to a chlorine release.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Carlsbad Municipal Water District Maerkle Facility (5203 Sunny Creek Road, Carlsbad, California) is owned and operated by Carlsbad MWD (headquartered at 5950 El Camino Real, Carlsbad, California), which is part of the City of Carlsbad.  The facility is located approximately 1.5 miles north of the intersection of El Camino Real / Palomar Airport Road, and approximately 1 mile west of Melrose Drive.  The facility is situated near the boundaries of the cities of Vista and Oceanside.

Two very similar chlorine water treatment systems are utilized at the facility:  Lower Maerkle and Upper Maerkle.  The chlorine systems were re-designed in 1995 accordance with applicable federal, state, and local regulations.  The Water Operations Department maintains a rotating Duty Operator who is on call 24/7 should any abnormal conditions arise.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The chlorine systems at the Carlsbad Municipal Water District (MWD) Maerkle Facility are used for the treatment of potable water used for distribution to the City of Carlsbad.  Chlorine is stored as a liquefied compressed gas in typical one-ton containers at two stations located at the Maerkle Facility:  Lower Maerkle, and Upper Maerkle.  Carlsbad Water Operations Department is responsible for a variety of behind the scenes services that keep our city running smoothly.  We are At Your Service and committed to providing top quality service to the Carlsbad community.

Carlsbad MWD's senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but to also implement safety and environmental programs that promote a safe environment for all employees, as well as the surrounding communities.  The Utilities Manager, Utilities Superintendent, and Utilities Supervisor are responsible for the operations of the chlorine facilities, and to ensure compliance with safety and environmental programs such as Cal-OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM), and EPAs Risk Management Program.  These programs also include Hazard Communication, Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP), safe work practices such as Confined Space and Respiratory Protection, manufacturer-recommended maintenance and inspections, emergency response planning with the local fire department and San Diego County HazMat Team, as well as the Risk Management Plan that is also on file with the San Diego County CUPA.

Carlsbad MWD has an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) in effect, which is detailed in the Emergency Planning & Response section of the PSM/RMP document maintained by the CMWD department.
